body: If a process in Linux has a file open, then that open survives a "rm" or "mv" operation. So, I suppose the time at which a new routine is bound to a session depends on when its library file is opened and its NARoutine info is cached. So, imagine this scenario: A library contains two UDFs, F1 and F2. A session opens, references F1. That library is now open, and F1's NARoutine information is cached. Now suppose another session does an ALTER LIBRARY. And after that, suppose the first session references F2. I think what happens is we'll open the new library (because library definitions are not cached, per @sureshsubbiah), and F2 will come from the new library. I'm guessing this is OK, but I wonder what happens if the implementations of F1 and F2 share code within the library. The answers might depend on whether it is C++ or Java (dlopen might have different rules than JVM class paths). It's probably a good idea to think this through a bit and update the documentation with any conclusions you might have.

Hi Selva, ALTER will not remove files. I think we have two options now

a) Document that ALTER LIBRARY will require a DCS restart or not document this feature at all until we have query invalidation for UDFs ready. i,e, document the restart issue in a wiki and not document the statement in the manual
b) Close this PR for now and revisit it when we have query validation for Routine objects.

Both options seem reasonable to me. Thanks for your input. I agree the feature is partial at best now.
+1 for a). It is perfectly normal and OK to do features incrementally. In the JIRA, might be good to describe what work remains.

I am ok with either of the options. However, it may be good to send an warning to the user about this because it is unique to this DDL command alone.  There is no easy way for the user to detect this anomaly if the user doesn't restart DCS,
Inadvertant change to this branch. will reopen new PR
@selvaganesang , sorry, I need to abandon this change, and have another one, I misread the code
wrong fix, close and will send out a new PR

Test seems to have failed since the command in installer is deprecated. 
MAybe the command issued itself needs an update ?
Here is the error from installer : 
2016-06-09 20:19:05 _**INFO: Setting HDFS ACLs for snapshot scan support
2016-06-09 20:19:11 *__ERROR: (/usr/bin/hdfs dfs -setfacl -R -m user:trafodion:rwx /hbase/archive) command failed
2016-06-09 20:19:11 *__ERROR: traf_cloudera_mods exited with error.
2016-06-09 20:19:11 *__ERROR: Please check log files.
2016-06-09 20:19:11 *_*ERROR: Exiting....
2016-06-09 20:19:12 + ret=255

"Test seems to have failed since the command in installer is deprecated." 
I think @sandhyasun  you are thinking of "hadoop dfs" which is deprecated... but as you can see it is using "hdfs dfs" which is not. 

This is related to changing the umask to 0002. Looks like these commands need to be changed to correspond with that. A jira needs to be created to deal with this issue and assigned, this problem is not solved currently.

The command seems to have worked in hdp and failed in cdh. Is it possible that /hbase/archive directory is not present in cdh. It might be good to display echo $? as part of the error log. It might give us some clue why the command failed. If the command fails due to non-existence of the directoryh  it should be ok to ignore this error

echo "**_INFO: Setting HDFS ACLs for snapshot scan support"
ssh -q -n $HDFS_NODE 'sudo su hdfs --command "' "$HADOOP_BIN_PATH"'/hdfs dfs -mkdir -p /hbase/archive"'
if [ $? != 0 ]; then
   echo "**_ERROR: ($HADOOP_BIN_PATH/hdfs dfs -mkdir -p /hbase/archive) command failed"
   exit -1
fi
ssh -q -n $HDFS_NODE 'sudo su hdfs --command "' "$HADOOP_BIN_PATH"'/hdfs dfs -chown hbase:hbase /hbase/archive"'
if [ $? != 0 ]; then
   echo "**_ERROR: ($HADOOP_BIN_PATH/hdfs dfs -chown hbase:hbase /hbase/archive) command failed"
   exit -1
fi
ssh -q -n $HDFS_NODE 'sudo su hdfs --command "' "$HADOOP_BIN_PATH"'/hdfs dfs -setfacl -R -m user:'"$TRAF_USER"':rwx /hbase/archive"'
if [ $? != 0 ]; then
   echo "**_ERROR: ($HADOOP_BIN_PATH/hdfs dfs -setfacl -R -m user:$TRAF_USER:rwx /hbase/archive) command failed"
   exit -1
fi
ssh -q -n $HDFS_NODE 'sudo su hdfs --command "' "$HADOOP_BIN_PATH"'/hdfs dfs -setfacl -R -m default:user:'"$TRAF_USER"':rwx /hbase/archive"'
if [ $? != 0 ]; then
   echo "**_ERROR: ($HADOOP_BIN_PATH/hdfs dfs -setfacl -R -m default:user:$TRAF_USER:rwx /hbase/archive) command failed"
   exit -1
fi
ssh -q -n $HDFS_NODE 'sudo su hdfs --command "' "$HADOOP_BIN_PATH"'/hdfs dfs -setfacl -R -m mask::rwx /hbase/archive"'
if [ $? != 0 ]; then
   echo "**_ERROR: ($HADOOP_BIN_PATH/hdfs dfs -setfacl -R -m mask::rwx /hbase/archive) command failed"
   exit -1
fi
In that case, is ACL enabled in cdh? If so, we can try without -R option.
I think this is fine to merge. Will wait a little bit in case my questions make you think otherwise.
Thanks for the careful review. Will submit a rework addressing the items you mentioned.

Hi Dave, Give me 2 more days please. Let me find out what ALTER statements are currently covered by Query Invalidation. If ALTER LIBRARY is indeed an outlier, then I would hesitate to merge this change as is. Either a warning or a change to include QI for this ALTER seems better. I will report back with my finding on QI for ALTER in a couple of days.
By the way, will there be a change to the manuals? (Is ALTER LIBRARY new syntax?)
Looks good to me. Thanks for making this change.
Nice set of changes. I might have found a bug or two. It's been a long time since we added a new data type to the engine. Nice work.
The catalog APIs for ODBC/JDBC need to expose that tinyint is supported in database via SQLTypeInfo and getTypeInfo calls. It can be done later too.
Response to Selva's comment. Yes, catalog odbc/jdbc apis will need to be enhanced when full support for jdbc/odbc tinyint is externalized. Thanks for pointing it out.

I made an incorrect statement above. The good news is that stale NARoutine objects will be cleared from NARoutine caches **for all users**. This is due to a change by @robertamarton which I had not considered in my previous responses. Sorry.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-trafodion/commit/8e97ff43a7e5324227704cad4ec3e770d521473f

When we clear NARoutine object from the local NARoutine cache, it causes through RMS shared memory for the object to be cleared from other caches on the cluster. Please see the method removeNARoutine2 in @robertamarton 's PR. The CLI call causes an SQL_QIKEY to be placed in shared memory, eventually accessible by other executors.

With this item cleared I think the ALTER LIBRARY statement can be included in the manual.

I checked what type of DDL statements will cause NATable/NARoutine caches to be cleared.
This was added by @mikehanlonathpdotcom in https://github.com/apache/incubator-trafodion/commit/1bd19cba4b2c4d43fd78a5a56172ad8bcb153e73 (and 2 subsequent commits). The list has grown since.

I see that these cases are covered. There could be more. 
alter table add column
alter table add check constraint
alter table add unique constraint
alter table add primary key
alter table add foreign key (RI)
alter table rename
alter table hbase options
alter table rename column
create index

drop column
drop check constraint
drop unique constraint
drop primary key
drop foreign key (RI)
drop index
Looks good to me, though the conflicts have to be resolved.
Merging this change to master now

+1. Looks good.
@traflm please let us know if you would like to merge the change as is or would prefer to address the issues @DaveBirdsall raised now.
